{"uri": "8183112292", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "07:25:00", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T07:25:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T07:22:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9333333373069763, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/politics/2986497-hungarys-u-turn-mark-rutte-no-longer-opposed-as-nato-chief-contender", "title": "Hungary's U-Turn: Mark Rutte No Longer Opposed as NATO Chief Contender | Politics", "body": "Hungary has shifted its stance and now supports Mark Rutte as the next NATO secretary-general. This change follows a meeting between Dutch Prime Minister Rutte and Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orban. The backing of Hungary removes a key obstacle, although Romania and Slovakia have not yet consented.\n\nHungary has dropped its opposition to Mark Rutte as the next NATO secretary-general, Dutch media reported on Tuesday, after the outgoing Dutch prime minister and his Hungarian counterpart met on the sidelines of a EU leaders meeting in Brussels.\n\nCiting sources, Dutch outlets NOS and RTL reported that Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orban did not reiterate his demand for an apology from Rutte for what Orban described last month as \"problematic\" opinions on Hungary. The apology had been one of the two conditions Hungary had put forward for approving Rutte as the successor to Jens Stoltenberg at the helm of NATO.\n\nThe other - the guarantee that Hungary would not have to provide funding for Ukraine or send personnel to the war-torn country - was met last week by Stoltenberg. This year, the United States, Britain, France and Germany all backed Rutte to succeed Stoltenberg, who will step down in October, as the head of NATO.\n\nTurkey told its allies in April it would also support Rutte. Now only Romania and Slovakia have not yet given a green light. NATO takes decisions by consensus, so any candidate needs the support of all 32 allies.\n\nRomanian President Klaus Iohannis said in March he was running for the NATO top job, arguing Eastern European states need better representation in Euro-Atlantic leadership roles.\n\n(This story has not been edited by Devdiscourse staff and is auto-generated from a syndicated feed.)", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8183104589", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "07:19:08", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T07:19:08Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T07:17:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9176470637321472, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/politics/2986491-hungary-drops-objection-to-mark-rutte-as-next-nato-secretary-general", "title": "Hungary Drops Objection to Mark Rutte as Next NATO Secretary-General | Politics", "body": "Hungary has dropped its opposition to Mark Rutte becoming the next NATO secretary-general, following a meeting between the outgoing Dutch prime minister and Hungary's leader. Previously, Hungary demanded an apology for 'problematic' opinions and guarantees about non-involvement in Ukraine. Key NATO members back Rutte, with only Romania and Slovakia yet to agree.\n\nHungary has dropped its opposition to Mark Rutte as the next NATO secretary-general, Dutch media reported on Tuesday, after the outgoing Dutch prime minister and his Hungarian counterpart met on the sidelines of a EU leaders meeting in Brussels. Citing sources, Dutch outlets NOS and RTL reported that Orban did not reiterate his demand for an apology from Rutte for what Orban described last month as \"problematic\" opinions on Hungary.\n\nThe apology had been one of the two conditions Hungary had put forward for approving Rutte as the successor to Jens Stoltenberg at the helm of NATO. The other - the guarantee that Hungary would not have to provide funding for Ukraine or send personnel to the war-torn country - was met last week by Stoltenberg.\n\nThis year, the United States, Britain, France and Germany all backed Rutte to succeed Stoltenberg, who will step down in October, as the head of NATO. Turkey told its allies in April it would also support Rutte. Now only Romania and Slovakia have not yet given a green light.\n\nNATO takes decisions by consensus, so any candidate needs the support of all 32 allies. Romanian President Klaus Iohannis said in March he was running for the NATO top job, arguing Eastern European states need better representation in Euro-Atlantic leadership roles.\n\n(This story has {"uri": "8184848132", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "07:30:17", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T07:30:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T07:29:37Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8784313797950745, "url": "https://www.firstpost.com/world/mark-rutte-set-to-succeed-stoltenberg-as-nato-chief-after-hungary-slovakia-back-him-13783874.html", "title": "Mark Rutte set to succeed Stoltenberg as NATO chief after Hungary, Slovakia back him", "body": "Dutch Prime Minister Mark Rutte speaks to the media on the day of a European Union leaders informal summit in Brussels, Belgium June 17, 2024. Reuters\n\nDutch Prime Minister Mark Rutte, a staunch ally of Kyiv and a critic of Russian President Vladimir Putin, will succeed Jens Stoltenberg as NATO chief, Dutch national broadcaster NOS reported on Tuesday, after Hungary and Slovakia backed him.\n\nSpeaking at a news conference alongside US Secretary of State Antony Blinken in Washington, Stoltenberg neither confirmed nor denied the media report.\n\n\"With the announcement of (Hungarian) Prime Minister (Viktor) Orban, I think it's obvious that we are very close to a conclusion &mldr; to select the next secretary-general, and I think that's good news,\" he told reporters while praising Rutte.\n\n\"I think Mark is a very strong candidate. He has a lot of experience as prime minister. He's a close friend and colleague, and I therefore strongly believe that very soon, the alliance will have decided on my successor,\" he said. \"And that will be good for all of us, for NATO and also for me.\"\n\nNATO's next secretary-general will face the challenge of sustaining allies' support for Ukraine's fight against Russia's invasion while guarding against any escalation that could draw the military alliance directly into a war with Moscow.\n\nIn the two years since Russia launched its full-scale invasion, Rutte has been one of the driving forces behind Europe's military support to Ukraine, stressing time and again what he said was the absolute need for a Russian battlefield defeat to secure peace in Europe.\n\nUnder his recent leadership, the Netherlands has ramped up defence spending above the 2 per cent threshold of GDP required of NATO members, providing F-16 fighter jets, artillery, drones and ammunition to Kyiv as well as investing heavily in its own military.\n\nRutte's support for Ukraine is underscored by his criticism of Russia and its President Vladimir Putin, as the Netherlands holds Russia accountable for the downing of passenger flight MH17 over eastern Ukraine in July 2014 - which killed all 298 passengers and crew, 196 of them from the Netherlands.\n\nHours before the NOS report, Hungary and Slovakia had given their support to the candidacy of Rutte, clearing a crucial hurdle on his way to NATO's top job.\n\nNATO makes decisions by consensus, so any candidate needs the support of all 32 allies. Only Romania, whose President Klaus Iohannis is also vying for the job, is still officially opposed to Rutte's candidacy.\n\nHungary's backing followed a meeting Orban had with Stoltenberg last week, where the two sides agreed that Hungary would not block NATO decisions on providing support for Ukraine but has agreed that it would not be involved.\n\nOrban drops opposition\n\n\"PM Mark Rutte confirmed that he fully supports this deal and will continue to do so, should he become the next Secretary General of NATO,\" Orban wrote on the X social media platform.\n\n\"In light of his pledge, Hungary is ready to support PM Rutte's bid for NATO Secretary-General.\"\n\nOrban had earlier opposed Rutte's candidacy because he had expressed \"problematic\" opinions that included the idea that Hungary should leave the European Union.\n\nHungary has been at odds with other NATO countries over Orban's continued cultivation of close ties with Russia and refusal to send arms to Ukraine, with Budapest's foreign minister last month labelling plans to help the war-torn nation a \"crazy mission.\"\n\nTurkey and Slovakia have also changed course on Rutte's bid, with Turkey saying it would support him in late April and Slovakia announcing its support earlier on Tuesday.\n\nSlovakia, which borders Ukraine, had stressed the need for the next NATO chief to help deal with the protection of Slovak airspace, its President Peter Pellegrini said, after the previous Slovak government donated an S-300 system to Ukraine, and allies pulled out Patriot batteries that had been temporarily placed there.\n\nStoltenberg's term will end on October 1, 10 years after taking office in 2014, just a few months after Russia annexed Crimea.\n\nDuring his tenure, Stoltenberg oversaw NATO's shift from an alliance mainly engaged in crisis management missions in far-off places such as Afghanistan back to its roots of defence against Russia.\n\nFour countries have joined NATO since Stoltenberg took office - Montenegro, North Macedonia, Finland and Sweden.\n\nBy giving the top job to Rutte, the alliance will pass the opportunity to see a woman, Estonian Prime Minister Kaja Kallas, take the helm of NATO for the first time - something several members had lobbied for.\n\nKallas, a candidate mainly touted by Eastern European countries, was seen as too hawkish towards Russia by some Western member states.", "source": {"uri": "firstpost.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Firstpost"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_the_Netherlands", {"uri": "2024-06-393324905", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "10:38:12", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T10:38:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T07:18:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8784313797950745, "url": "https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/hungary-not-opposed-ruttes-candidacy-nato-top-job-anymore-dutch-media-reports-2024-06-18/", "title": "Hungary not opposed to Rutte's candidacy for NATO top job anymore, Dutch media reports", "body": "AMSTERDAM, June 18 (Reuters) - Hungary has dropped its opposition to Mark Rutte as the next NATO secretary-general, Dutch media reported on Tuesday, after the outgoing Dutch prime minister and his Hungarian counterpart met on the sidelines of a EU leaders meeting in Brussels.\n\nCiting sources, Dutch outlets NOS and RTL reported that Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orban did not reiterate his demand for an apology from Rutte for what Orban described last month as \"problematic\" opinions on Hungary.\n\nThe apology had been one of the two conditions Hungary had put forward for approving Rutte as the successor to Jens Stoltenberg at the helm of NATO.\n\nThe other - the guarantee that Hungary would not have to provide funding for Ukraine or send personnel to the war-torn country - was met last week by Stoltenberg.\n\nThis year, the United States, Britain, France and Germany all backed Rutte to succeed Stoltenberg, who will step down in October, as the head of NATO.\n\nTurkey told its allies in April it would also support Rutte. Now only Romania and Slovakia have not yet given a green light.\n\nNATO takes decisions by consensus, so any candidate needs the support of all 32 allies.\n\nRomanian President Klaus Iohannis said in March he was running for the NATO top job, arguing Eastern European states need better representation in Euro-Atlantic leadership roles.\n\nReporting by Benoit Van Overstraeten; Editing by Gerry Now only Romania and Slovakia have not yet given a green light.\n\nNato takes decisions by consensus, so any candidate needs the support of all 32 allies.\n\nRomanian president Klaus Iohannis said in {"uri": "8184139237", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "18:55:50", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T18:55:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T18:54:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8588235378265381, "url": "https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2024/6/18/orban-says-hungary-ready-to-back-dutch-pm-ruttes-nato-chief-bid", "title": "Orban says Hungary 'ready' to back Dutch PM Rutte's NATO chief bid", "body": "Move comes after Rutte offered assurances he wouldn't force Hungary to partake in NATO plans to provide support to Kyiv.\n\nHungary's Prime Minister Victor Orban has backed Mark Rutte to become the next head of NATO after the outgoing Dutch prime minister gave written guarantees that he would not force the country to take part in the military alliance's new plans to provide support to Ukraine.\n\nRutte's assurances, contained in a letter to Orban, remove a major obstacle to him becoming the next NATO secretary-general - the organisation's top civilian official.\n\nIt could also allow NATO to put on a major show of unity and demonstrate solidarity with war-ravaged Ukraine when US President Joe Biden and his counterparts meet in Washington on July 9-11. The summit is to mark NATO's 75th anniversary.\n\nAt talks in Budapest last week, NATO Secretary-General Jens Stoltenberg, who is due to step down in October, clinched a deal with Orban to ensure that Hungary would not block NATO's plans for Ukraine.\n\nStoltenberg accepted that Hungary should not be obligated to provide personnel or funds for the collective effort, but Orban wanted to hear it from Rutte, too.\n\nNATO takes all of its decisions by consensus, giving any of the 32 member countries an effective veto, including on whether they should take part in any joint effort or operation.\n\nTaking to social media, Orban said it was important for Hungary to establish \"that this agreement can stand the test of time.\"\n\nHe posted Rutte's letter, dated June 18, a day after the two men had met in Brussels on the sidelines of a European Union summit.\n\nRutte wrote that \"in a possible future capacity as NATO Secretary General I will fully support this outcome of the talks between Jens Stoltenberg and you.\"\n\nIt was enough for Orban.\n\n\"PM Mark Rutte confirmed that he fully supports this deal and will continue to do so, should he become the next Secretary General of NATO. In light of his pledge, Hungary is ready to support PM Rutte's bid for NATO Secretary-General,\" he posted on X.\n\nBudapest had also complained about unidentified remarks that Rutte had made about the Hungarian government three years ago and demanded an apology.\n\nRutte wrote that he \"took note\" that his past remarks \"caused dissatisfaction in Hungary. My priority in a possible future capacity as NATO Secretary General will be to maintain unity and treat all Allies with the same level of understanding and respect\".\n\nFollowing Hungary's announcement, Dutch national broadcaster NOS reported that Rutte will succeed Stoltenberg as NATO chief.\n\nSpeaking at a news conference alongside US Secretary of State Antony Blinken in Washington, Stoltenberg neither confirmed nor denied the media report.\n\n\"With the announcement of ... Orban, I think it's obvious that we are very close to a conclusion ... to select the next secretary-general, and I think that's good news,\" he told reporters, while praising Rutte.\n\n\"I think Mark is a very strong candidate. He has a lot of experience as prime minister. He's a close friend and colleague, and I therefore strongly believe that very soon, the alliance will have decided on my successor,\" he said. \"And that will be good for all of us, for NATO and also for me.\"\n\nNATO secretaries-general are responsible for chairing meetings and guiding sometimes delicate consultations among member countries to ensure that an organisation that operates on consensus can continue to function.\n\nRutte is far and away the preferred candidate of the majority of NATO allies, including the United States and Germany. Earlier this year, Turkey voiced opposition to Rutte's bid but lifted its objections in April.\n\nThe candidature of Romanian President Klaus Iohannis, who is nearing the end of his second five-year term as head of state, remains a hurdle but officials and analysts believe it will not pose a major problem.\n\nStoltenberg is seen as a steady hand at NATO's helm for a decade and his mandate has been extended several times. Biden and his NATO counterparts had been due to name a successor when they met in Lithuania in July 2023, but no consensus could be found about a replacement.\n\n\"I mean it sincerely, you've been great. I just wish you'd extend your term another 10 years,\" Biden said as he met the former Norwegian prime minister at the White House on Monday.", "source": {"uri": "aljazeera.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8187249018", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "14:55:16", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T14:55:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T14:54:08Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8549019694328308, "url": "https://ommcomnews.com/world-news/romania-clears-way-for-dutch-pm-rutte-to-become-nato-chief", "title": "Romania Clears Way For Dutch PM Rutte To Become NATO Chief | World", "body": "Bucharest: Romania is endorsing Dutch Prime Minister Mark Rutte to become NATO Secretary General, clearing the final hurdle on Rutte's path to the top job, according to a press release published by the office of Romanian President Klaus Iohannis on Thursday.\n\nIohannis had put himself forward for the role, but \"informed his NATO allies at the end of last week that he had withdrawn his candidacy for the post,\" the press release said.\n\nOn Thursday, Romania's Supreme Council of National Defence \"declared themselves in favour of Romania's support for the Dutch prime minister's candidacy,\" according to the statement.\n\nThe announcement means no obstacles remain to Rutte becoming the next NATO chief. Romania was the only NATO country that had not yet endorsed Rutte, who needs the unanimous support of all 32 member states. Hungary and Slovakia endorsed Rutte after a European Union leaders' summit earlier this week.\n\nThe term of current Secretary General Jens Stoltenberg is due to end on October 1. In Washington on Tuesday, Stoltenberg said: \"I think it's obvious that we are very close to a conclusion in the alliance, for allies to select the next secretary general. And I think that's good news.\"\n\nRomania's opposition to Rutte's candidacy followed from its support for Iohannis, the country's head of state. But Romania's northwestern neighbour, Hungary, resisted Rutte in particular until this week.\n\nHungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orban ended his opposition on Tuesday. \"Hungary is ready to support PM Rutte's bid for NATO Secretary General,\" Orb\u00e1n said on X, alongside a copy of a letter from Rutte promising to respect an agreement between Orb\u00e1n and the current secretary general, Jens Stoltenberg, that Hungary will not be required to contribute to Ukraine's war effort.\n\nRutte's letter, also dated Tuesday, noted that remarks he made in 2021 \"have caused dissatisfaction in Hungary. My priority in a possible future capacity as NATO Secretary General will be to maintain unity and treat all Allies with the same level of understanding and respect.\"\n\nEU leaders have accused Orban's government of undermining the rule of law in Hungary, and European Union courts have also ruled against Budapest.\n\nRutte and Orban met on Monday ahead of a dinner for EU leaders in Brussels, after which Rutte told reporters that he would soon be sending a letter to Orban. Rutte told members of the press that the Hungarian premier had not asked him to apologize, and that they were focused on the \"future.\"\n\nSlovakia's new president, Peter Pellegrini, also said in Brussels on Monday that his country would back Rutte, Slovakian national news agency TASR reported.\n\nStoltenberg said on Tuesday: \"I think Mark Rutte is a very strong candidate. He has a lot of experience as Prime Minister. He's a close friend and colleague, and I therefore strongly believe that very soon the Alliance will have decided on my successor, and that will be good for all of us, for NATO and also for me,\" he {"uri": "8184622320", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "04:13:47", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T04:13:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T04:13:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8470588326454163, "url": "https://www.ariananews.af/dutch-pm-rutte-to-succeed-stoltenberg-as-nato-chief-media-reports/", "title": "Dutch PM Rutte to succeed Stoltenberg as NATO chief, media reports | Ariana News", "body": "Speaking at a news conference alongside U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken in Washington, Stoltenberg neither confirmed nor denied the media report.\n\nDutch Prime Minister Mark Rutte, a staunch ally of Kyiv and a critic of Russian President Vladimir Putin, will succeed Jens Stoltenberg as NATO chief, Dutch national broadcaster NOS reported on Tuesday, after Hungary and Slovakia backed him, Reuters reported.\n\nSpeaking at a news conference alongside U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken in Washington, Stoltenberg neither confirmed nor denied the media report.\n\n\"With the announcement of (Hungarian) Prime Minister (Viktor) Orban, I think it's obvious that we are very close to a conclusion ... to select the next secretary-general, and I think that's good news,\" he told reporters, while praising Rutte.\n\n\"I think Mark is a very strong candidate. He has a lot of experience as prime minister. He's a close friend and colleague, and I therefore strongly believe that very soon, the alliance will have decided on my successor,\" he said. \"And that will be good for all of us, for NATO and also for me.\"\n\nNATO's next secretary-general will face the challenge of sustaining allies' support for Ukraine's fight against Russia's invasion, while guarding against any escalation that could draw the military alliance directly into a war with Moscow, read the report.\n\nIn the two years since Russia launched its full-scale invasion, Rutte has been one of the driving forces behind Europe's military support to Ukraine, stressing time and again what he said was the absolute need for a Russian battlefield defeat to secure peace in Europe.\n\nUnder his recent leadership, the Netherlands has ramped up defence spending above the 2% threshold of GDP required of NATO members, providing F-16 fighter jets, artillery, drones and ammunition to Kyiv as well as investing heavily in its own military.\n\nRutte's support for Ukraine is underscored by his criticism of Russia and its President Vladimir Putin, as the Netherlands holds Russia accountable for the downing of passenger flight MH17 over eastern Ukraine in July 2014 - which killed all 298 passengers and crew, 196 of them from the Netherlands.\n\nHours before the NOS report, Hungary and Slovakia had given their support to the candidacy of Rutte, clearing a crucial hurdle on his way to NATO's top job.\n\nNATO takes decisions by consensus, so any candidate needs the support of all 32 allies. Only Romania, whose President Klaus Iohannis is also vying for the job, is still officially opposed to Rutte's candidacy.\n\nHungary's backing followed a meeting Orban had with Stoltenberg last week, where the two sides agreed that Hungary would not block NATO decisions on providing support for Ukraine but has agreed that it would not be involved.\n\nORBAN DROPS OPPOSITION\n\n\"PM Mark Rutte confirmed that he fully supports this deal and will continue to do so, should he become the next Secretary General of NATO,\" Orban wrote on the X social media platform.\n\n\"In light of his pledge, Hungary is ready to support PM Rutte's bid for NATO Secretary-General.\"\n\nOrban had earlier opposed Rutte's candidacy because he had expressed \"problematic\" opinions that included the idea that Hungary should leave the European Union.\n\nHungary has been at odds with other NATO countries over Orban's continued cultivation of close ties with Russia and refusal to send arms to Ukraine, with Budapest's foreign minister last month labelling plans to help the war-torn nation a \"crazy mission.\"\n\nTurkey and Slovakia have also changed course on Rutte's bid, with Turkey saying it would support him in late April and Slovakia announcing its support earlier on Tuesday, Reuters reported.\n\nSlovakia, which borders Ukraine, had stressed the need for the next NATO chief to help deal with the protection of Slovak airspace, its President Peter Pellegrini said, after the previous Slovak government donated an S-300 system to Ukraine, and allies pulled out Patriot batteries that had been temporarily placed there.\n\nStoltenberg's term will end on October 1, 10 years after taking office in 2014, just a few months after Russia annexed Crimea.\n\nDuring his tenure, Stoltenberg oversaw NATO's shift from an alliance mainly engaged in crisis management missions in far-off places such as Afghanistan back to its roots of defence against Russia.\n\nFour countries have joined NATO since Stoltenberg took office - Montenegro, North Macedonia, Finland and Sweden, read the report.\n\nBy giving the top job to Rutte, the alliance will pass the opportunity to see a woman, Estonian Prime Minister Kaja Kallas, take the helm of NATO for the first time - something several members had lobbied for.\n\nKallas, a candidate mainly touted by eastern European countries, was seen as too hawkish towards Russia by some western member states.\n\nBiden, Zelenskiy inch toward NATO with 10-year defense agreement", "source": {"uri": "ariananews.af", "dataType": "news", "title": "Ariana News"}, All of the military alliance's 32 members must approve a candidate for the four-year term.\n\nDutch RTL News on June 18 quoted unnamed sources as saying Budapest \"no longer opposes [Rutte's] candidacy\" after a meeting between Rutte and Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orban on the sidelines of an EU leaders' meeting.\n\nOrban spokesman Zoltan Kovacs confirmed on the social network X that Orban and Rutte had met late on June 17 ahead of the EU summit to focus on \"bilateral and international issues.\"\n\nDutch outlet NOS quoted Orban's spokesman as saying the Hungarian prime minister and Rutte had a \"good conversation.\"\n\nThere has been no public word from Hungarian officials of any change of position.\n\nOrban had said earlier this month that he would end his opposition to Rutte's NATO candidacy if he apologized for recent criticism of his government in Budapest and permitted Hungary to exclude itself from the military alliance's higher aid plans to Ukraine.\n\nRutte said on June 17 that he remained \"cautiously optimistic about Hungary.\"\n\nThen on June 18, new Slovak President Peter Pellegrini said his country is prepared to support Rutte for the NATO top job.\n\n\"After a final discussion with Mark Rutte and consultation with the Slovak government, Slovakia can imagine Mark Rutte as the NATO chief,\" Reuters quoted Pellegrini telling a televised news briefing.\n\nSlovaks are among the most pro-Russian of EU and NATO members, and left-wing populist Prime Minister Robert Fico halted arms shipments to Ukraine after his appointment as prime minister in October.\n\nLike Orban, Fico has also publicly opposed Ukraine's eventual membership in NATO.\n\nPellegrini, who is regarded as a Fico ally, was sworn in to replace staunch Ukraine supporter Zuzana Caputova as president on June 15.\n\nOrban has been a staunch critic of sanctions and direct military assistance to Kyiv since Russia invaded Ukraine two years ago, and he has continued visits and other diplomatic overtures to Moscow despite Western calls for unity in the face of the Russian threat.\n\nHe and his national populist Fidesz party have also spearheaded anti-EU sentiment within and outside the bloc that seemingly contributed to right-wing gains in this month's elections for the European Parliament.\n\nStoltenberg traveled to Hungary on June 12 and emerged from a meeting with Orban saying Budapest had agreed not to block assistance and military aid to Ukraine, although it would exercise an opt-out.\n\nRomanian President Klaus Iohannis has sought the NATO leadership job for Now only Romania and Slovakia have not yet given a green light.\n\nNATO takes decisions by consensus, so any candidate needs the support of all 32 allies.\n\nRomanian President Klaus Iohannis said in March he was running for the NATO top job, arguing Eastern European states need better representation in Euro-Atlantic leadership roles.\n\n(Reporting by Benoit Van Overstraeten; Editing by Gerry {"uri": "8184132075", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "18:49:35", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T18:49:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T18:48:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.843137264251709, "url": "https://thewest.com.au/news/conflict/dutch-pm-rutte-to-become-new-nato-chief-media-report-c-15066967", "title": "Dutch PM Rutte to become new NATO chief: media report", "body": "Dutch PM Rutte to become new NATO chief: media reportStaff WritersReutersWed, 19 June 2024 2:42AM\n\nDutch Prime Minister Mark Rutte, a staunch ally of Ukraine and a critic of Russian President Vladimir Putin, will succeed Jens Stoltenberg as NATO chief, Dutch national broadcaster NOS reports after Hungary and Slovakia backed him.\n\nSpeaking at a news conference alongside US Secretary of State Antony Blinken in Washington DC, Stoltenberg neither confirmed nor denied the media report.\n\n\"With the announcement of (Hungarian) Prime Minister (Viktor) Orban, I think it's obvious that we are very close to a conclusion ... to select the next secretary-general, and I think that's good news,\" he told reporters, while praising Rutte.\n\n\"I think Mark is a very strong candidate. He has a lot of experience as prime minister. He's a close friend and colleague, and I therefore strongly believe that very soon, the alliance will have decided on my successor,\" he said.\n\nTheNightlyGet in front of tomorrow's news for FREE\n\nJournalism for the curious Australian across politics, business, culture and opinion.\n\nREAD NOW\n\n\"And that will be good for all of us, for NATO and also for me.\"\n\nNATO's next secretary-general will face the challenge of sustaining allies' support for Ukraine's fight against Russia's invasion, while guarding against any escalation that could draw the military alliance directly into a war with Russia.\n\nIn the two years since Russia launched its full-scale invasion, Rutte has been one of the driving forces behind European military support to Ukraine, stressing time and again what he said was the absolute need for a Russian battlefield defeat to secure peace on the continent.\n\nUnder his recent leadership, the Netherlands has ramped up defence spending above the two per cent threshold of GDP required of NATO members, providing F-16 fighter jets, artillery, drones and ammunition to Ukraine as well as investing heavily in its own military.\n\nRutte's support for Ukraine is underscored by his criticism of Russia and its President Vladimir Putin, as the Netherlands holds Russia accountable for the downing of passenger flight MH17 over eastern Ukraine in July 2014 - which killed all 298 passengers and crew.\n\nHours before the NOS report, Hungary and Slovakia had given their support to the candidacy of Rutte, clearing a crucial hurdle on his way to the NATO military alliance's top job.\n\nNATO takes decisions by consensus, so any candidate needs the support of all 32 allies.\n\nOnly Romania, whose President Klaus Iohannis is also vying for the job, is still officially opposed to Rutte's candidacy.\n\nHungary's backing followed a meeting Orban had with Stoltenberg last week, where the two sides agreed that Hungary would not block NATO decisions on providing support for Ukraine but has agreed that it would not be involved.\n\n\"PM Mark Rutte confirmed that he fully supports this deal and will continue to do so, should he become the next Secretary General of NATO,\" Orban wrote on the X social media platform.\n\n\"In light of his pledge, Hungary is ready to support PM Rutte's bid for NATO Secretary-General.\"\n\nOrban had earlier opposed Rutte's candidacy because he had expressed \"problematic\" opinions that included the idea that Hungary should leave the European Union.\n\nHungary has been at odds with other NATO countries over Orban's continued cultivation of close ties with Russia and refusal to send arms to Ukraine, with the Hungarian foreign minister last month labelling plans to help the war-torn country a \"crazy mission\".\n\nTurkey and Slovakia have also changed course on Rutte's bid, with Turkey saying it would support him in late April and Slovakia announcing its support earlier on Tuesday.\n\nSlovakia, which borders Ukraine, had stressed the need for the next NATO chief to help deal with the protection of Slovak airspace, its President Peter Pellegrini said, after the previous Slovak government donated an S-300 system to Ukraine and allies pulled out Patriot batteries that had been temporarily placed there.\n\nStoltenberg's term will end on October 1, 10 years after taking office in 2014, just a few months after Russia annexed Crimea.\n\nDuring his tenure, Stoltenberg oversaw NATO's shift from an alliance mainly engaged in crisis management missions in far-off places such as Afghanistan back to its roots of defence against Russia.\n\nFour countries have joined NATO since Stoltenberg took office - Montenegro, North Macedonia, Finland and Sweden.\n\nGet the latest news from {"uri": "8184103203", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "18:24:53", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T18:24:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T18:23:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8352941274642944, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/politics/2987405-mark-rutte-poised-to-become-nato-secretary-general", "title": "Mark Rutte Poised to Become NATO Secretary-General | Politics", "body": "Dutch Prime Minister Mark Rutte is set to succeed Jens Stoltenberg as NATO Secretary-General. Known for his strong support of Ukraine and criticism of Russia, Rutte secured backing from Hungary and Slovakia, despite earlier opposition. He aims to maintain robust alliances within NATO amid ongoing geopolitical tensions.\n\nDutch Prime Minister Mark Rutte, a staunch ally of Kyiv and a critic of Russian President Vladimir Putin, will succeed Jens Stoltenberg as NATO chief, Dutch national broadcaster NOS reported on Tuesday, after Hungary and Slovakia backed him.\n\nSpeaking at a news conference alongside U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken in Washington, Stoltenberg neither confirmed nor denied the media report. \"With the announcement of (Hungarian) Prime Minister (Viktor) Orban, I think it's obvious that we are very close to a conclusion ... to select the next secretary-general, and I think that's good news,\" he told reporters, while praising Rutte.\n\n\"I think Mark is a very strong candidate. He has a lot of experience as prime minister. He's a close friend and colleague, and I therefore strongly believe that very soon, the alliance will have decided on my successor,\" he said. \"And that will be good for all of us, for NATO and also for me.\" NATO's next secretary-general will face the challenge of sustaining allies' support for Ukraine's fight against Russia's invasion, while guarding against any escalation that could draw the military alliance directly into a war with Moscow.\n\nIn the two years since Russia launched its full-scale invasion, Rutte has been one of the driving forces behind Europe's military support to Ukraine, stressing time and again what he said was the absolute need for a Russian battlefield defeat to secure peace in Europe. Under his recent leadership, the Netherlands has ramped up defence spending above the 2% threshold of GDP required of NATO members, providing F-16 fighter jets, artillery, drones and ammunition to Kyiv as well as investing heavily in its own military.\n\nRutte's support for Ukraine is underscored by his criticism of Russia and its President Vladimir Putin, as the Netherlands holds Russia accountable for the downing of passenger flight MH17 over eastern Ukraine in July 2014 - which killed all 298 passengers and crew, 196 of them from the Netherlands. Hours before the NOS report, Hungary and Slovakia had given their support to the candidacy of Rutte, clearing a crucial hurdle on his way to NATO's top job.\n\nNATO takes decisions by consensus, so any candidate needs the support of all 32 allies. Only Romania, whose President Klaus Iohannis is also vying for the job, is still officially opposed to Rutte's candidacy. Hungary's backing followed a meeting Orban had with Stoltenberg last week, where the two sides agreed that Hungary would not block NATO decisions on providing support for Ukraine but has agreed that it would not be involved.\n\nORBAN DROPS OPPOSITION \"PM Mark Rutte confirmed that he fully supports this deal and will continue to do so, should he become the next Secretary General of NATO,\" Orban wrote on the X social media platform.\n\n\"In light of his pledge, Hungary is ready to support PM Rutte's bid for NATO Secretary-General.\" Orban had earlier opposed Rutte's candidacy because he had expressed \"problematic\" opinions that included the idea that Hungary should leave the European Union.\n\nHungary has been at odds with other NATO countries over Orban's continued cultivation of close ties with Russia and refusal to send arms to Ukraine, with Budapest's foreign minister last month labelling plans to help the war-torn nation a \"crazy mission.\" Turkey and Slovakia have also changed course on Rutte's bid, with Turkey saying it would support him in late April and Slovakia announcing its support earlier on Tuesday.\n\nSlovakia, which borders Ukraine, had stressed the need for the next NATO chief to help deal with the protection of Slovak airspace, its President Peter Pellegrini said, after the previous Slovak government donated an S-300 system to Ukraine, and allies pulled out Patriot batteries that had been temporarily placed there. Stoltenberg's term will end on October 1, 10 years after taking office in 2014, just a few months after Russia annexed Crimea.\n\nDuring his tenure, Stoltenberg oversaw NATO's shift from an alliance mainly engaged in crisis management missions in far-off places such as Afghanistan back to its roots of defence against Russia. Four countries have joined NATO since Stoltenberg took office - Montenegro, North Macedonia, Finland and Sweden.\n\nBy giving the top job to Rutte, the alliance will pass the opportunity to see a woman, Estonian Prime Minister Kaja Kallas, take the helm of NATO for the first time - something several members had lobbied for. Kallas, a candidate mainly touted by eastern European countries, was seen as too hawkish towards Russia by some western member states.\n\n(This story has not been edited by Devdiscourse staff and is auto-generated from a syndicated feed.)", "source": {"uri": "devdiscourse.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Devdiscourse"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-06-393872099", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "19:17:04", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T19:17:04Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T19:10:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8352941274642944, "url": "https://indianexpress.com/article/world/dutch-pm-rutte-succeed-stoltenberg-nato-chief-9400761/", "title": "Dutch PM Rutte to succeed Stoltenberg as NATO chief, media reports | World News - The Indian Express", "body": "Speaking at a news conference alongside US Secretary of State Antony Blinken in Washington, Stoltenberg neither confirmed nor denied the media report.\n\nDutch Prime Minister Mark Rutte, a staunch ally of Kyiv and a critic of Russian President Vladimir Putin, will succeed Jens Stoltenberg as NATO chief, Dutch national broadcaster NOS reported on Tuesday, after Hungary and Slovakia backed him.\n\nSpeaking at a news conference alongside US Secretary of State Antony Blinken in Washington, Stoltenberg neither confirmed nor denied the media report.\n\n\"With the announcement of (Hungarian) Prime Minister (Viktor) Orban, I think it's obvious that we are very close to a conclusion ... to select the next secretary-general, and I think that's good news,\" he told reporters, while praising Rutte.\n\n\"I think Mark is a very strong candidate. He has a lot of experience as prime minister. He's a close friend and colleague, and I therefore strongly believe that very soon, the alliance will have decided on my successor,\" he said. \"And that will be good for all of us, for NATO and also for me.\"\n\nNATO's next secretary-general will face the challenge of sustaining allies' support for Ukraine's fight against Russia's invasion, while guarding against any escalation that could draw the military alliance directly into a war with Moscow.\n\nIn the two years since Russia launched its full-scale invasion, Rutte has been one of the driving forces behind Europe's military support to Ukraine, stressing time and again what he said was the absolute need for a Russian battlefield defeat to secure peace in Europe.\n\nUnder his recent leadership, the Netherlands has ramped up defence spending above the 2% threshold of GDP required of NATO members, providing F-16 fighter jets, artillery, drones and ammunition to Kyiv as well as investing heavily in its own military.\n\nRutte's support for Ukraine is underscored by his criticism of Russia and its President Vladimir Putin, as the Netherlands holds Russia accountable for the downing of passenger flight MH17 over eastern Ukraine in July 2014 - which killed all 298 passengers and crew, 196 of them from the Netherlands.\n\nAlso Read: | Record number of NATO allies are hitting their defense spending target during war in Ukraine\n\nHours before the NOS report, Hungary and Slovakia had given their support to the candidacy of Rutte, clearing a crucial hurdle on his way to NATO's top job.\n\nNATO takes decisions by consensus, so any candidate needs the support of all 32 allies. Only Romania, whose President Klaus Iohannis is also vying for the job, is still officially opposed to Rutte's candidacy. Hungary's backing followed a meeting Orban had with Stoltenberg last week, where the two sides agreed that Hungary would not block NATO decisions on providing support for Ukraine but has agreed that it would not be involved.\n\nORBAN DROPS OPPOSITION\n\n\"PM Mark Rutte confirmed that he fully supports this deal and will continue to do so, should he become the next Secretary General of NATO,\" Orban wrote on the X social media platform. \"In light of his pledge, Hungary is ready to support PM Rutte's bid for NATO Secretary-General.\"\n\nOrban had earlier opposed Rutte's candidacy because he had expressed \"problematic\" opinions that included the idea that Hungary should leave the European Union.\n\nHungary has been at odds with other NATO countries over Orban's continued cultivation of close ties with Russia and refusal to send arms to Ukraine, with Budapest's foreign minister last month labelling plans to help the war-torn nation a \"crazy mission.\"\n\nTurkey and Slovakia have also changed course on Rutte's bid, with Turkey saying it would support him in late April and Slovakia announcing its support earlier on Tuesday.\n\nSlovakia, which borders Ukraine, had stressed the need for the next NATO chief to help deal with the protection of Slovak airspace, its President Peter Pellegrini said, after the previous Slovak government donated an S-300 system to Ukraine, and allies pulled out Patriot batteries that had been temporarily placed there.\n\nAlso Read: | Putin pledges ceasefire in Ukraine if Kyiv withdraws from occupied regions and drops NATO bid\n\nStoltenberg's term will end on October 1, 10 years after taking office in 2014, just a few months after Russia annexed Crimea. During his tenure, Stoltenberg oversaw NATO's shift from an alliance mainly engaged in crisis management missions in far-off places such as Afghanistan back to its roots of defence against Russia.\n\nFour countries have joined NATO since Stoltenberg took office - Montenegro, North Macedonia, Finland and Sweden.\n\nBy giving the top job to Rutte, the alliance will pass the opportunity to see a woman, Estonian Prime Minister Kaja Kallas, take the helm of NATO for the first time - something several members had lobbied for. Kallas, a candidate mainly touted by eastern European countries, was seen as too hawkish towards Russia by some western member states.", "source": {"uri": "indianexpress.com", "dataType": "news", My priority in a possible future capacity as NATO Secretary General will be to maintain unity and treat all Allies with the same level of understanding and respect.\"\n\nEU leaders have accused Orban's government of undermining the rule of law in Hungary, and European Union courts have also ruled against Budapest.\n\nRutte and Orban met on Monday ahead of a dinner for EU leaders in Brussels, after which Rutte told reporters that he would soon be sending a letter to Orban. Rutte told members of the press that the Hungarian premier had not asked him to apologise, and that they were focused on the \"future.\"\n\nSlovakia's new president, Peter Pellegrini, also said on Monday that his country would back Rutte, Slovakian national news agency TASR reported.\n\nHowever, Rutte still needs to win the support of Romania, where President Klaus Iohannis has put his own name {"uri": "8184129201", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "18:46:22", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T18:46:22Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T18:45:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8235294222831726, "url": "https://www.perthnow.com.au/news/conflict/dutch-pm-rutte-to-become-new-nato-chief-media-report-c-15066972", "title": "Dutch PM Rutte to become new NATO chief: media report", "body": "Dutch Prime Minister Mark Rutte, a staunch ally of Ukraine and a critic of Russian President Vladimir Putin, will succeed Jens Stoltenberg as NATO chief, Dutch national broadcaster NOS reports after Hungary and Slovakia backed him.\n\nSpeaking at a news conference alongside US Secretary of State Antony Blinken in Washington DC, Stoltenberg neither confirmed nor denied the media report.\n\n\"With the announcement of (Hungarian) Prime Minister (Viktor) Orban, I think it's obvious that we are very close to a conclusion ... to select the next secretary-general, and I think that's good news,\" he told reporters, while praising Rutte.\n\n\"I think Mark is a very strong candidate. He has a lot of experience as prime minister. He's a close friend and colleague, and I therefore strongly believe that very soon, the alliance will have decided on my successor,\" he said.\n\n\"And that will be good for all of us, for NATO and also for me.\"\n\nNATO's next secretary-general will face the challenge of sustaining allies' support for Ukraine's fight against Russia's invasion, while guarding against any escalation that could draw the military alliance directly into a war with Russia.\n\nIn the two years since Russia launched its full-scale invasion, Rutte has been one of the driving forces behind European military support to Ukraine, stressing time and again what he said was the absolute need for a Russian battlefield defeat to secure peace on the continent.\n\nUnder his recent leadership, the Netherlands has ramped up defence spending above the two per cent threshold of GDP required of NATO members, providing F-16 fighter jets, artillery, drones and ammunition to Ukraine as well as investing heavily in its own military.\n\nRutte's support for Ukraine is underscored by his criticism of Russia and its President Vladimir Putin, as the Netherlands holds Russia accountable for the downing of passenger flight MH17 over eastern Ukraine in July 2014 - which killed all 298 passengers and crew.\n\nHours before the NOS report, Hungary and Slovakia had given their support to the candidacy of Rutte, clearing a crucial hurdle on his way to the NATO military alliance's top job.\n\nNATO takes decisions by consensus, so any candidate needs the support of all 32 allies.\n\nOnly Romania, whose President Klaus Iohannis is also vying for the job, is still officially opposed to Rutte's candidacy.\n\nHungary's backing followed a meeting Orban had with Stoltenberg last week, where the two sides agreed that Hungary would not block NATO decisions on providing support for Ukraine but has agreed that it would not be involved.\n\n\"PM Mark Rutte confirmed that he fully supports this deal and will continue to do so, should he become the next Secretary General of NATO,\" Orban wrote on the X social media platform.\n\n\"In light of his pledge, Hungary is ready to support PM Rutte's bid for NATO Secretary-General.\"\n\nOrban had earlier opposed Rutte's candidacy because he had expressed \"problematic\" opinions that included the idea that Hungary should leave the European Union.\n\nHungary has been at odds with other NATO countries over Orban's continued cultivation of close ties with Russia and refusal to send arms to Ukraine, with the Hungarian foreign minister last month labelling plans to help the war-torn country a \"crazy mission\".\n\nTurkey and Slovakia have also changed course on Rutte's bid, with Turkey saying it would support him in late April and Slovakia announcing its support earlier on Tuesday.\n\nSlovakia, which borders Ukraine, had stressed the need for the next NATO chief to help deal with the protection of Slovak airspace, its President Peter Pellegrini said, after the previous Slovak government donated an S-300 system to Ukraine and allies pulled out Patriot batteries that had been temporarily placed there.\n\nStoltenberg's term will end on October 1, 10 years after taking office in 2014, just a few months after Russia annexed Crimea.\n\nDuring his tenure, Stoltenberg oversaw NATO's shift from an alliance mainly engaged in crisis management missions in far-off places such as Afghanistan back to its roots of defence against Russia.\n\nFour countries have joined NATO since Stoltenberg took office - Montenegro, North Macedonia, Finland and {"uri": "8184126464", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "18:44:12", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T18:44:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T18:43:15Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8196078538894653, "url": "https://www.theglobeandmail.com/world/article-dutch-pm-mark-rutte-to-reportedly-succeed-stoltenberg-as-nato-chief/", "title": "Dutch PM Mark Rutte to reportedly succeed Stoltenberg as NATO chief", "body": "Dutch Prime Minister Mark Rutte, a staunch ally of Kyiv and a critic of Russian President Vladimir Putin, will succeed Jens Stoltenberg as NATO chief, Dutch national broadcaster NOS reported on Tuesday, after Hungary and Slovakia backed him.\n\nSpeaking at a news conference alongside U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken in Washington, Stoltenberg neither confirmed nor denied the media report.\n\n\"With the announcement of (Hungarian) Prime Minister (Viktor) Orban, I think it's obvious that we are very close to a conclusion ... to select the next secretary-general, and I think that's good news,\" he told reporters, while praising Rutte.\n\n\"I think Mark is a very strong candidate. He has a lot of experience as prime minister. He's a close friend and colleague, and I therefore strongly believe that very soon, the alliance will have decided on my successor,\" he said. \"And that will be good for all of us, for NATO and also for me.\"\n\nNATO's next secretary-general will face the challenge of sustaining allies' support for Ukraine's fight against Russia's invasion, while guarding against any escalation that could draw the military alliance directly into a war with Moscow.\n\nIn the two years since Russia launched its full-scale invasion, Rutte has been one of the driving forces behind Europe's military support to Ukraine, stressing time and again what he said was the absolute need for a Russian battlefield defeat to secure peace in Europe.\n\nUnder his recent leadership, the Netherlands has ramped up defence spending above the 2% threshold of GDP required of NATO members, providing F-16 fighter jets, artillery, drones and ammunition to Kyiv as well as investing heavily in its own military.\n\nRutte's support for Ukraine is underscored by his criticism of Russia and its President Vladimir Putin, as the Netherlands holds Russia accountable for the downing of passenger flight MH17 over eastern Ukraine in July 2014 - which killed all 298 passengers and crew, 196 of them from the Netherlands.\n\nHours before the NOS report, Hungary and Slovakia had given their support to the candidacy of Rutte, clearing a crucial hurdle on his way to NATO's top job.\n\nNATO takes decisions by consensus, so any candidate needs the support of all 32 allies. Only Romania, whose President Klaus Iohannis is also vying for the job, is still officially opposed to Rutte's candidacy.\n\nHungary's backing followed a meeting Orban had with Stoltenberg last week, where the two sides agreed that Hungary would not block NATO decisions on providing support for Ukraine but has agreed that it would not be involved.\n\n\"PM Mark Rutte confirmed that he fully supports this deal and will continue to do so, should he become the next Secretary General of NATO,\" Orban wrote on the X social media platform.\n\n\"In light of his pledge, Hungary is ready to support PM Rutte's bid for NATO Secretary-General.\"\n\nOrban had earlier opposed Rutte's candidacy because he had expressed \"problematic\" opinions that included the idea that Hungary should leave the European Union.\n\nHungary has been at odds with other NATO countries over Orban's continued cultivation of close ties with Russia and refusal to send arms to Ukraine, with Budapest's foreign minister last month labelling plans to help the war-torn nation a \"crazy mission.\"\n\nTurkey and Slovakia have also changed course on Rutte's bid, with Turkey saying it would support him in late April and Slovakia announcing its support earlier on Tuesday.\n\nSlovakia, which borders Ukraine, had stressed the need for the next NATO chief to help deal with the protection of Slovak airspace, its President Peter Pellegrini said, after the previous Slovak government donated an S-300 system to Ukraine, and allies pulled out Patriot batteries that had been temporarily placed there.\n\nStoltenberg's term will end on October 1, 10 years after taking office in 2014, just a few months after Russia annexed Crimea.\n\nDuring his tenure, Stoltenberg oversaw NATO's shift from an alliance mainly engaged in crisis management missions in far-off places such as Afghanistan back to its roots of defence against Russia.\n\nFour countries have joined NATO since Stoltenberg took office - Montenegro, North Macedonia, Finland and Sweden.\n\nBy giving the top job to Rutte, the alliance will pass the opportunity to see a woman, Estonian Prime Minister Kaja Kallas, take the helm of NATO for the first time - something several members had lobbied for.\n\nKallas, a candidate mainly touted by eastern European countries, was seen as too hawkish towards Russia by some western member states.", "source": {"uri": "theglobeandmail.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Globe and Mail"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mark_Rutte", "type": {"uri": "8185276863", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "12:10:33", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T12:10:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T12:09:54Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8196078538894653, "url": "https://www.euronews.com/2024/06/19/dutch-pm-mark-rutte-in-line-to-become-next-nato-chief-after-hungary-lifts-veto", "title": "Dutch PM Rutte in line to become NATO chief after Hungary lifts veto", "body": "Earlier, Hungary's Prime Minister Viktor Orban had vetoed his outgoing Dutch counterpart for the military alliance's top job over objections including spending the country's money on supporting Ukraine.\n\nMark Rutte is lined up to become the next head of NATO after Budapest lifted its veto on the deal following a letter sent by Rutte to Hungarian PM Viktor Orb\u00e1n.\n\nThe letter appeased the Hungarian premier that, as head of NATO, Rutte would not deploy Budapest's military or spend Hungary's money on supporting Ukraine.\n\nAfter Orb\u00e1n announced he had dropped his previous objections to the outgoing Dutch prime minister, incumbent NATO Secretary General Jens Stoltenberg reported that the selection process would end \"very soon\".\n\nOrban posted a copy of the letter he was sent on X, writing, \"After yesterday's meeting in Brussels ... Rutte confirmed that he fully supports this deal and will continue to do so, should he become the next Secretary General of NATO.\"\n\nIn his letter, Rutte wrote that he would honour the deal cinched between Stoltenberg and Orban in Budapest last week, which confirmed that Hungary would be left out of NATO's support for Ukraine.\n\nRutte also mentioned that he had taken note of unidentified remarks he had made about Hungary in 2021 that had caused dissatisfaction within the Hungarian government.\n\nThe 57-year-old Dutch politician assured Orban in writing that Hungary's troops and funds would not be involved in NATO's support for Ukraine.\n\nDecisions in NATO are made via consensus between all members. Therefore, Hungary's veto on Rutte's leadership meant that he was blocked from ascending to the top position in the alliance.\n\nRutte has the approval of most NATO allies, including the US and Germany. Turkey previously opposed Rutte's bid but backtracked into approving him in April.\n\nAmong the 32 member states of the alliance, only Romania remains undeclared. The country's President Klaus Iohannis announced his own bid to become the next NATO secretary general in March, yet failed to drum up as much support as Rutte.\n\nRutte is known for being the longest-serving Dutch PM in history, having led four coalition governments since 2010.\n\nNATO is set to hold its annual summit in Washington in July, after which Rutte is expected to take over the helm of the alliance from Stoltenberg. The summit will focus on how to ensure long-term military support for Ukraine.\n\nAs head of NATO, Rutte would have to decide how to support Ukraine and deal with potential US president Donald Trump during his tenure. Trump is a well-known sceptic of the alliance and has threatened to quit unless other members boost their defence spending.", "source": {"uri": "euronews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Euronews Viktor Orban.\n\nAfter winning the backing of key powers, Rutte is the clear frontrunner to take over as head of the alliance when current leader Jens Stoltenberg's term ends this year.\n\nBut he has struggled to win over Orban and still faces competition from the only other candidate, Romanian President Klaus Iohannis.\n\n\"I'm cautiously optimistic about Hungary,\" Rutte told journalists after meeting Orban on the sidelines of an EU summit in Brussels.\n\nOrban said this month he could drop his objections if Rutte apologises for previous comments slamming the right-wing government in Budapest, and allows Hungary to stay out of NATO's plans to boost aid for Ukraine.\n\nRutte said Orban \"didn't ask for an apology, and I said that obviously I took note of what happened in Hungary in terms of societal reactions to what I said a couple of years ago\".\n\n\"We left it at that, taking note of, and very much looking at the future and he didn't ask for any apology,\" Rutte said, adding grant Hungary an opt-out on NATO plans to aid Ukraine.\n\nLeading NATO powers spearheaded by the United States are pressing to get an agreement on a new head of the alliance by a summit in Washington My priority in a possible future capacity as NATO Secretary General will be to maintain unity and treat all Allies with the same level of understanding and respect\".\n\nEU leaders have accused Orban's government of undermining the rule of law in Hungary, and European Union courts have also ruled against Budapest.\n\nRutte and Orban met on Monday ahead of a dinner for EU leaders in Brussels, after which Rutte told reporters that he would soon be sending a letter to Orban.\n\nRutte told members of the press that the Hungarian premier had not asked him to apologise and that they were focused on the \"future\".\n\nSlovakia's new President, Peter Pellegrini, also said on Monday that his country would back Rutte, Slovakian national news agency TASR reported.\n\nIn Washington on Tuesday, Stoltenberg said: \"Normally, I don't say anything about my successor, because it's not for me to select my successor. But with the announcement by President or, sorry, Prime Minister Orban today, I think it's obvious that we are very close to a conclusion in the Alliance, for Allies to select the next Secretary General. And I think that's good news.\"\n\n\"I think Mark Rutte is a very strong candidate. He has a lot of experience as Prime Minister. He's a close friend and colleague, and I therefore strongly believe that very soon the Alliance will have decided on my successor, and that will be good for all of us, for NATO and also for me,\" he {"uri": "8184391137", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "23:22:03", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T23:22:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T23:20:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8156862854957581, "url": "https://www.eurasiareview.com/19062024-romania-now-last-hurdle-for-rutte-as-nato-chief-after-hungary-slovakia-sign-on/", "title": "Romania Now Last Hurdle For Rutte As NATO Chief After Hungary, Slovakia Sign On", "body": "(RFE/RL) -- Romania remains the final country yet to give its support to longtime Dutch Prime Minister Mark Rutte becoming NATO's next secretary-general after Hungary dropped its objections following meetings in Brussels and Slovakia's president appeared to signal his country's support.\n\nThe transatlantic military alliance is seeking the required consensus among its 32 members for someone to succeed Norwegian Jens Stoltenberg as secretary-general when he steps down in October.\n\nThe United States, Britain, France, Germany, and Turkey have all said they would support Rutte's candidacy.\n\nOne of the main holdouts, Hungary, dropped its resistance on June 18 when Prime Minister Viktor Orban said Rutte had agreed to honor an agreement reached with Stoltenberg that that no Hungarian personnel will take part in the activities of NATO in Ukraine and no Hungarian funds will be used to support them.\n\n\"In light of his pledge, Hungary is ready to support PM Rutte's bid for NATO Secretary-General,\" Orban said in a post on X, formerly Twitter.\n\nStoltenberg, speaking at a news conference in Washington, said Orban's announcement made it \"obvious that we are very close to a conclusion in the alliance. I think that's good news. I think that Mark Rutte is a very strong candidate.\"\n\nRutte said on June 17 that he remained \"cautiously optimistic about Hungary.\"\n\nEarlier on June 18, new Slovak President Peter Pellegrini said his country was prepared to support Rutte for the NATO top job.\n\n\"After a final discussion with Mark Rutte and consultation with the Slovak government, Slovakia can imagine Mark Rutte as the NATO chief,\" Reuters quoted Pellegrini as telling a televised news briefing.\n\nRutte is now on the verge of the unanimous support he needs to be chosen for the position, with only Romania undeclared among the military alliance's 32 members to approve the Dutch politician for a four-year term.\n\nSlovaks are among the most pro-Russian of EU and NATO members, and left-wing populist Prime Minister Robert Fico halted arms shipments to Ukraine after his appointment as prime minister in October.\n\nLike Orban, Fico has also publicly opposed Ukraine's eventual membership in NATO.\n\nPellegrini, who is regarded as a Fico ally, was sworn in to replace staunch Ukraine supporter Zuzana Caputova as president on June 15.\n\nOrban has been a staunch critic of sanctions and direct military assistance to Kyiv since Russia invaded Ukraine two years ago, and he has continued visits and other diplomatic overtures to Moscow despite Western calls for unity in the face of the Russian threat.\n\nHe and his national populist Fidesz party have also spearheaded anti-EU sentiment within and outside the bloc that seemingly contributed to right-wing gains in this month's elections for the European Parliament.\n\nStoltenberg traveled to Hungary on June 12 and emerged from a meeting with Orban saying Budapest had agreed not to block assistance and military aid to Ukraine, although it would exercise an opt-out.\n\nRomanian President Klaus Iohannis has sought the NATO leadership job for himself.", "source": {"uri": "eurasiareview.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Eurasia Review"}, {"uri": "8187056427", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "12:56:04", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T12:56:04Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T12:52:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8156862854957581, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/romania-clears-way-dutch-pm-124604709.html", "title": "Romania clears way for Dutch PM Rutte to become NATO chief", "body": "Romania is endorsing Dutch Prime Minister Mark Rutte to become NATO secretary general, clearing the final hurdle on Rutte's path to the top job, according to a press release published by the office of Romanian President Klaus Iohannis on Thursday.\n\nIohannis had put himself forward for the role, but \"informed his NATO allies at the end of last week that he had withdrawn his candidacy for the post,\" the press release said.\n\nOn Thursday, Romania's Supreme Council of National Defence \"declared themselves in favour of Romania's support for the Dutch prime minister's candidacy,\" according to the statement.\n\nThe announcement means no obstacles remain to Rutte becoming the next NATO chief. Romania was the only NATO country that had not yet endorsed Rutte, who needs the unanimous support of all 32 member states. Hungary and Slovakia endorsed Rutte after a European Union leaders' summit earlier this week.\n\nThe term of current Secretary General Jens Stoltenberg is due to end on October 1. In Washington on Tuesday, Stoltenberg said: \"I think it's obvious that we are very close to a conclusion in the alliance, for allies to select the next secretary general. And I think that's good news.\"\n\nRomania's opposition to Rutte's candidacy followed from its support for Iohannis, the country's head of state. But Romania's northwestern neighbour, Hungary, resisted Rutte in particular until this week.\n\nHungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orb\u00e1n ended his opposition on Tuesday. \"Hungary is ready to support PM Rutte's bid for NATO Secretary General,\" Orb\u00e1n said on X, alongside a copy of a letter from Rutte promising to respect an agreement between Orb\u00e1n and the current secretary general, Jens Stoltenberg, that Hungary will not be required to contribute to Ukraine's war effort.\n\nRutte's letter, also dated Tuesday, noted that remarks he made in 2021 \"have caused dissatisfaction in Hungary. My priority in a possible future capacity as NATO Secretary General will be to maintain unity and treat all Allies with the same level of understanding and respect.\"\n\nEU leaders have accused Orb\u00e1n's government of undermining the rule of law in Hungary, and European Union courts have also ruled against Budapest.\n\nRutte and Orb\u00e1n met on Monday ahead of a dinner for EU leaders in Brussels, after which Rutte told reporters that he would soon be sending a letter to Orb\u00e1n. Rutte told members of the press that the Hungarian premier had not asked him to apologize, and that they were focused on the \"future.\"\n\nSlovakia's new president, Peter Pellegrini, also said in Brussels on Monday that his country would back Rutte, Slovakian national news agency TASR reported.\n\nStoltenberg said on Tuesday: \"I think Mark Rutte is a very strong candidate. He has a lot of experience as Prime Minister. He's a close friend and colleague, and I therefore strongly believe that very soon the Alliance will have decided on my successor, and that will be good for all of us, for NATO and also for me,\" he {"uri": "8187765635", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "22:10:46", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T22:10:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T22:08:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8117647171020508, "url": "https://www.bostonglobe.com/2024/06/20/world/clearing-final-hurdle-dutch-leader-is-poised-become-nato-chief/", "title": "Clearing a final hurdle, Dutch leader is poised to become NATO chief - The Boston Globe", "body": "That could take place as soon as next week, before a high-level NATO summit in Washington in July. The Netherlands is a founding member, and Rutte would be the fourth Dutch official to become the organization's top diplomat.\n\nEven if that happens, he would not immediately assume responsibility for the 32-nation alliance. Rutte, who has been the leader of the Netherlands since 2010, remains prime minister in the country's transitional government, and a diplomat who requested anonymity, in line with protocol, said the current NATO secretary general, Jens Stoltenberg, was for now expected to stay until his term ends in October.\n\nRutte has increasingly echoed a main NATO message that supporting Ukraine in its defensive war against Russia is vital for preserving democracy and national sovereignty across the alliance.\n\n\"This war is not simply about defending the freedom of the Ukrainian people; it is also about protecting the freedom and security of the Netherlands,\" Rutte is quoted as saying at the top of his government's website. \"So we will not abandon those most in need.\"\n\nStill, Rutte is not seen as unwilling to deal with Russia or with Moscow's few allies in NATO, as had been the case with some candidates from Eastern Europe or the Baltic states who also had expressed interest in the top job.\n\n\"It is a consensus organization, so you have 32 allies that you need to bring on board,\" said Camille Grand, a former NATO assistant secretary general who is now at the European Council on Foreign Relations. \"If you're perceived as leaning toward one particular geography of the alliance, or too dovish or too hawkish, then it makes things complicated.\n\n\"There was a concern that it was important to have someone who is perceived as in the middle ground of the alliance, rather than on the edges of the debate,\" Grand said. \"So he was ticking all the boxes.\"\n\nGrand knew and worked with Rutte when they overlapped at NATO headquarters in Brussels. \"He was always pretty mainstream in the room,\" Grand said. \"He was never the guy who was difficult on anything, but always very supportive of NATO, sometimes even to the point of criticizing his peers when they were not loyal enough.\"\n\nRutte's criticism of Hungary in 2021 was seen as almost costing him the top NATO job.\n\nHungary is both a member of NATO and of the European Union, and its leader, Prime Minister Viktor Orban, has exasperated officials in both organizations for imposing some authoritarian policies and maintaining relations with President Vladimir Putin of Russia. In 2021, Orban's government restricted LGBTQ+ content in the media and schools, eliciting \"deep concern\" from EU leaders and prompting Rutte to declare that Hungary \"has no business being in the European Union anymore.\"\n\nThat set off three years of acrimony between the two men and led to suggestions by Orban that he would not support Rutte's candidacy as the NATO chief, whose election requires unanimous consent within the alliance. But Orban backed down last week as part of an agreement that Hungary would not provide or otherwise support NATO efforts to continue sending military aid to Ukraine for the duration of the war.\n\nIn a letter to Orban on Tuesday, Rutte said he would respect that agreement \"in a possible future capacity as NATO secretary general.\"\n\nBut Rutte stopped just short of apologizing for his remarks about Hungary.\n\n\"I also took note that some remarks I made in 2021 as prime minister of the Netherlands have caused dissatisfaction in Hungary,\" Rutte wrote in the letter, dated Tuesday. \"My priority in a possible future capacity as NATO secretary general will be to maintain unity and treat allies with the same level of understanding and respect.\"\n\nNATO allies who backed Rutte's bid have sought to lock down support before the July meeting in Washington. Iohannis, the Romanian president, dropped out of the running after Orban's concession made it clear that Rutte's bid had widespread support. On Thursday, Iohannis endorsed Rutte and announced that Romania would send one of its urgently needed Patriot air defense systems to Ukraine.\n\nRutte announced last July that he would not seek reelection in the Netherlands after his government was split over the issue of Dutch asylum for migrants and refugees.\n\nIn October, he told Dutch radio that he found the job of NATO's civilian chief \"very interesting,\" and by February, he had secured the backing of the United States and of European powers.\n\nRutte is not married, lives in the same house in The Hague that he bought as a student with friends, and often rides his bike to work.", "source": {"uri": "bostonglobe.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Boston Globe"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8186165857", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "01:42:59", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T01:42:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T01:41:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8078431487083435, "url": "https://global.chinadaily.com.cn/a/202406/20/WS6673878da31095c51c509dbd.html", "title": "Outgoing Dutch PM to land NATO top job: Media", "body": "Mark Rutte, the outgoing Dutch prime minister, is on course to become the next head of the NATO military alliance, replacing current Secretary-General Jens Stoltenberg, Dutch national broadcaster NOS reported on Tuesday, after Hungary and Slovakia backed him.\n\nSpeaking at a news conference alongside US Secretary of State Antony Blinken in Washington, Stoltenberg neither confirmed nor denied the media report.\n\n\"With the announcement of (Hungarian) Prime Minister (Viktor) Orban, I think it's obvious that we are very close to a conclusion ...to select the next secretary-general, and I think that's good news,\" he told reporters, while praising Rutte.\n\n\"I think Mark is a very strong candidate.... He's a close friend and colleague, and I therefore strongly believe that very soon, the alliance will have decided on my successor,\" Stoltenberg said.\n\nOrban had announced that he had no objection to Rutte's appointment.\n\nHungary's close ties with Russia left Orban in a position of significant influence when it came to the appointment process.\n\nHungary has been at odds with other NATO countries over Hungary's ties with Russia and refusal to send arms to Ukraine.\n\nOrban's backing means that, of the 32 members of the military alliance, only Romania has yet to give its backing to Rutte, and that is expected soon.\n\nTurkiye and Slovakia have also changed course on Rutte's bid, with Ankara saying it would support him in late April and Slovakia announcing its support earlier on Tuesday.\n\nRutte will step down from the domestic role he has held for 14 years once the new Dutch coalition government is formed.\n\nUnder his leadership, the Netherlands has ramped up defense spending above the 2 percent threshold of GDP required of NATO members, providing F-16 fighter jets, artillery, drones and ammunition to Kyiv as well as investing heavily in its own military.\n\nOn the global stage, Rutte is regarded as being one of the most successful figures from within the European Union in dealing with former US president Donald Trump, who is standing for reelection later this year.\n\nAt last year's Munich Security Conference, Rutte told world leaders they should stop \"moaning and whining about Trump\", and spend more on their own defense and munitions production.\n\nStoltenberg's term will end on Oct 1, 10 years after taking office in 2014.NATO's annual summit will be held in Washington next month, after which Rutte is expected to take over as its new supremo.\n\nAfter Rutte gained the backing of nearly all alliance members, Romanian President Klaus Iohannis said on Wednesday he would address whether he will continue his bid to become the next chief of NATO at a state defense council meeting on Thursday.\n\n\"After (the meeting) I will tell the public. "sim": 0.8078431487083435, "url": "https://www.spacewar.com/afp/240618144617.1hbm3odp.html", "title": "Hungary 'ready to support' Dutch PM Rutte's NATO bid: Orban", "body": "\"Hungary is ready to support PM Rutte's bid for NATO secretary general,\" Orban posted on X after the two leaders met on the sidelines of an EU summit in Brussels.\n\nOrban's backing removes a major hurdle for Rutte to take the helm of the trans-Atlantic alliance, leaving only Romanian President Klaus Iohannis as the sole other candidate.\n\nExcept for Romania, all other 31 NATO countries appear ready to give their support to Rutte, whose nomination requires consensus from all allies.\n\nOrban said he gave the green light after getting a guarantee from Rutte that he would stick to a deal agreed by Orban with current NATO chief Jens Stoltenberg last week over NATO's plan to coordinate arms deliveries to Ukraine.\n\nUnder the deal, Budapest would \"not block\" plans for the alliance to play a bigger role in the arms shipments, but Hungary would not have to contribute to the initiative.\n\n\"Our next step this week was to ensure that this agreement can stand the test of time,\" Orban posted, along with a photo of him and Rutte shaking hands and a letter signed by Rutte.\n\nMeanwhile, media reports in Slovakia, which had been sitting on the fence on Rutte's appointment, said Tuesday that President Peter Pellegrini had endorsed Rutte in return for help from the Dutch in securing air defence equipment.\n\nNATO diplomats said they expect Romania's Iohannis to announce soon that he was withdrawing from the race, though there was still no formal word from Bucharest.\n\nRutte would likely assume office when Stoltenberg's term ends on October 1.\n\nIn the letter posted by Orban, Rutte also \"took
